title: East Africa: Much Ado About Sugar, but Times Must Change
text:
Kenya: Sugar's Popular Lies Vs Unpopular Truth 
Last weekend, however, Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta's state visit to Uganda suggested the locomotive of regional integration can roll faster were it not lacking a political wheel. 
After a couple of hours of deliberations with his host President Yoweri Museveni, the two heads of state resolved with the stroke of a pen outstanding trade disputes over sugar, beef, maize and milk. 
They also reached agreement on the route an oil pipeline that is expected to take crude oil from the Lake Albert and northern Kenya fields would take and that Kenya would invest in a Ugandan plant manufacturing anti-retroviral drugs. 
Regional issues were not left out, with pledges of increased co-operation in the anti-terror war, with integrating South Sudan's education system into that of EAC countries and Kenya exporting 35 Megawatts of power to Rwanda under the East Africa Power Pool also featuring. 
Predictably, discourse on the agreements has centred on who stands to lose what rather what the accords herald for the two economies and regional integration in the long run. 
In Kenya, President Kenyatta was seemingly agitated by criticism from opposition leader Raila Odinga and other politicians that sugar imports from Uganda sound a death knell for the country's sugarcane farmers and millers. 
The fear of a backlash was so real that even Foreign Ministry officials appeared to recant that indeed such an agreement, contained in a dispatch from State House, no less, existed. 
Lessons from the collapsed Community and the bold steps taken so far suggest that protection of industries, no matter how strategic, has no place in a globalised world where a cutting edge in efficiency and customer satisfaction are the key movers of sales. 
Kenya's sugar sector, safeguarded by quotas from lower-cost producers in East and Southern Africa, has been unable to reform, with mismanagement leading to frequent stock-outs and piling indebtedness. 
Despite the safeguards that are perennially renewed, imported sugar is readily available in the country thanks to repackaging of smuggled sugar for sale, including by the managers of leading sugar millers themselves. 
EAC members should take the cue from the hard decisions taken by Kenya and Uganda to expose inefficient sectors to competition. That will shock them into adopting best business practices and laying a foundation for future growth, expansion and job creation. East Africa
